questions.text: A young sportsman presented to opd with the complaint of severe groin pain. which of the following investigation is useful to rule out Gilmore's groin ?
questions.solution:
• Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) can help in the diagnosis of sportsman's (Gilmore's) groin, where pain is the presenting feature and the surgeon needs to distinguish an occult hernia from an orthopedic injury.

Remember: in occult hernia or sportsman hernia, only presenting symptom is pain. No visible swelling is seen.


Topic: GILMORE'S GROIN

Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery; 28th edition; chapter 64 ; page number 1062.

questions.text: A 25 years old male patient presented to opd with the complaint of abdominal distension. On an ultrasound of the abdomen there was gross free fluid in the abdominal cavity. On paracentèsis of ascitic fluid the protein was 20 g / L. All of the following are the possible causes for this ascites except_______
questions.solution:
• Hypo-proteinaemia results in reduced oncotic pressure and also causes a transudate, for example from a nephrotic syndrome or protein losing enteropathy.
  • An exudate represents protein rich fluid (protein > 25 g/L) formed secondary to hemorrhage, infection, inflammation or neoplasia.

Topic: Transudates Vs Exudates

Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery; 28th edition; chapter 65 ; page number 1092.

questions.text: A 40 years old Indian woman has weight of 100 kg and height of 162 cm. Which class of obesity is seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
BMI = person's weight in kilograms divided by the square of his/her height in meters.

BMI = 100 / 1.62 * 1.62 = 38.10 Kg /m2


Topic: BMI

choices.text: This is an autosomal dominant condition.
Melanin spots can also occur on the digits and perianal skin.
Mutation of STK 11 gene on chromosome 19 has been found in a proportion of patients.
Malignant changes in the polyps are common, so it requires regular check up.

questions.text: A 20 yrs old male patient was admitted to the emergency department with intestinal obstruction. On examination, his clinical photograph is given below. All of the following statements are true about this condition except ________
questions.solution:
• This is an autosomal dominant condition characterized by melanosis of the mouth and lips, with multiple hamartomatous (benign tumor-like malformations resulting from faulty development in an organ) polyps in the small bowel and colon.
  • Melanin spots can also occur on the digits and perianal skin. Mutation of the STK11 gene on chromosome 19 has been found in a proportion of patients.
  • Regular colonic surveillance should be performed and female patients should attend breast and cervical screening. Despite the increased risk of malignancy in general, malignant change in the polyps themselves is uncommon.
  • Peutz Jeghers Disease
    • P -Pigmentation (circumoral)
    • J- Jejunal polyps
    • D- Dominant (Autosomal)

Topic: peutz-jeghers syndrome

Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery; 28th edition; chapter 74 ; page number :1309.

questions.text: A 18 years old female patient had a stenosing type of Crohn's disease in the ileum. Classify this patient according to the MONTREAL CLASSIFICATION
questions.solution:
• Each patient with CD shuld have their disease phenotype (manifestations) classified according to the Montreal classification. This is important as it allows an overview of disease progression in the individual patient over time, and enables group comparisons and evaluations. The Montreal classification specifies age at diagnosis, behavior and disease location.


Topic: The Montreal classification of Crohn's disease

Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery; 28th edition; chapter 75 ; page number:1329.

choices.text: Any degree of mental alteration ( encephalopathy )
Illness of less than 26 weeks duration

questions.text: According to the American association for the study of liver disease, the definition of acute liver failure contains all of the following components except_____
questions.solution:
• Acute liver failure is the development of sudden, severe hepatic dysfunction from an acute insult associated with the onset of hepatic encephalopathy and coagulation abnormalities. The most widely accepted definition, from the American Association for the Study of Liver Diseases, is:

"evidence of coagulation abnormality, usually an international normalized ratio above 1.5, and any degree of mental alteration (encephalopathy) in a patient without pre-existing liver disease and with an illness of less than 26 weeks' duration."

Topic: Acute liver failure

Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery; 28th edition; chapter 69 ; page number:1194.

questions.text: A 55 year old male patient presented to emergency with complaints of upper abdominal pain, fever and anorexia for the last 7 days. Patient was alcoholic. On examination the patient had tachycardia, and tenderness in epigastric and right hypochondria. On CT scan, Patient was diagnosed as a case of liver abscess. The cut section of CT scan is given below. Which is the liver abscess in the given CT scan ?
questions.solution:
• Liver abscess appears as peripherally enhancing, centrally hypoattenuating lesions on CT scan.
  • Hemangiomas appear hypoattenuating relative to adjacent liver in CT scan.


Topic: Liver abscess

questions.text: All of the following are the components of the FELTY'S SYNDROME except____
questions.solution:
• Patients with rheumatoid arthritis may develop leukopenia.
  • This is referred to as Felty's syndrome if it is extreme and associated with splenomegaly.
  • Splenectomy produces only a transient improvement in the blood picture, but rheumatoid arthritis may respond to steroid therapy to which it had previously become resistant.

Topic: Felty's syndrome

Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery; 28 th edition; chapter 70 ; page number:1229.

questions.text: The intraoperative image of laparoscopic cholecystectomy is given below. The sulcus seen on the right side of the starting of black line is the anatomical location of______
questions.solution:
• Rouvière's sulcus on the undersurface of the right lobe of the liver running to the right of the hepatic hilum marks the position of the right posterior sectoral pedicle. The advantage of identifying Rouvière's sulcus and the line joining the roof of the sulcus to the base of segment IV (R4U line) (Rouvière's sulcus→segment IV→umbilical fissure) is that the cystic duct and the cystic artery lie ventral (anterosuperior) to the line and the CBD lies below the line.
  • It is important to identify safe (above the line) and danger ( below the R4U line ) zones of dissection as demarcated by the R4U line.

Topic: R4U line

Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery;28th edition; chapter 71 ; page number:1234.

questions.text: A 45 yrs old female patient was admitted for vague upper abdominal pain. Her x-ray is given below. What is your diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
• A plain radiograph of the gallbladder will show radio-opaque stones in 10% . It may also show calcification of the gallbladder - the rare "porcelain" gallbladder.
  • Porcelain gallbladder is associated with an increased risk for gallbladder cancer.

  • Gas may be seen in the wall of the gallbladder (emphysematous cholecystitis. Gas in the biliary tree may also be seen after endoscopic sphincterotomy or following a surgical anastomosis.

Topic: Porcelain gall bladder

Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery; 28th edition; chapter 71; page number:1234, 1235.

questions.text: Which of the variations of the gallbladder is the most common from the below given images ?
questions.solution:
The Phrygian cap

  • The Phrygian cap is present in 5% of gallbladders and may be mistaken for pathological deformity.it is mostly asymptomatic and requires no management.

Topic: Variations in gallbladder and duct anatomy

Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery; 28th edition; chapter 71 ; page number:1239.

questions.text:
All of the following statements are true about annular pancreas_____
1) This is the result of failure of complete rotation of the ventral pancreatic bud during development, so that a ring of pancreatic tissue surrounds the second or third part of the duodenum.
2) It is most often seen in association with congenital duodenal stenosis or atresia and is therefore more prevalent in children with Down syndrome.
3) Duodenal obstruction typically causes vomiting in the neonate.
4) The usual treatment is bypass (duodenoduodenostomy).
questions.solution:
• This is the result of failure of complete rotation of the ventral pancreatic bud during development, so that a ring of pancreatic tissue surrounds the second or third part of the duodenum.
  • It is most often seen in association with congenital duodenal stenosis or atresia and is therefore more prevalent in children with Down syndrome.
  • Duodenal obstruction typically causes vomiting in the neonate.
  • The usual treatment is bypass (duodenoduodenostomy).
  • The diagnosis may be made in later life as a cause of pancreatitis, in which case resection of the head of the pancreas should be considered.

Topic: Annular pancreas

Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery; 28th edition; chapter 72 ; page number:1267.

questions.text: A 42 years old alcoholic male patient presented to opd with the complaints of upper abdominal pain, weight loss and diabetes. He had a past history of multiple episodes of acute pancreatitis. His MRCP report is given below. What is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
• Epigastric abdominal pain radiating to the back, steatorrhea, malnutrition, and diabetes mellitus are hallmark features of chronic pancreatitis.
  • It is associated with stricture, dilatation or stone in the main pancreatic duct.

Pancreatic divisum


Topic: Investigations in chronic pancreatitis

Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery; 28th edition; chapter 72; page number:1279.

Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery; 28th edition; chapter 72 ; page number:1280.

questions.text: A 23 years old, obese female, smoker female patient presented to opd with complaints of painful skin abscess and scarring in the right axilla as seen in her clinical photograph. What is your diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
option A : lipodystrophy

  • Lipodystrophy (lipoatrophy) is a localized or generalized loss of fatty tissue, which can be primary or secondary. It can be a complication of long-term administration of insulin, following treatment of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) with protease inhibitors or in transplant recipients.
  • It can be treated in selected cases by autologous fat grafting, injections of poly-l-lactic acid and free tissue transfer.

option B : Hyperhidrosis

This involves excessive eccrine sweating of the palms, soles of the feet, axillae and groins, causing functional and social problems. It can be treated with antiperspirants or periodic local injections with botulinum toxin A. More resistant cases are treated by transthoracic endoscopic sympathectomy.

Option C : Hidradenitis suppurativa

Characterized by follicular occlusion, folliculitis and secondary infection (usually with Staphylococcus aureus and Propionibacterium acnes), hidradenitis suppurativa culminates in chronic suppurative, painful skin abscesses, sinus tracts and scarring. It affects apocrine gland-bearing skin in the axillae, groins and, less often, scalp, breast, chest and perineum.

Affecting four women for every man, it has a genetic predisposition, but variable penetrance, and is strongly associated with obesity, smoking and sex hormones (it starts at puberty and often resolves at menopause).

  • Management :
    • Patients should stop smoking and lose excess weight.
    • Symptoms can be reduced by the use of antiseptic soaps, tea tree oil and wearing non-compressive and aerated underwear.
    • Medical treatments include topical and oral antibiotics and antiandrogen drugs.
    • In selected cases, patients require radical excision of the affected skin and subcutaneous tissue.
    • Reconstruction after excision avoids contracture and functional impairment.

Option D :

Characterized by rapid onset and painful cutaneous ulceration with purple undermined edges, pyoderma gangrenosum is secondary to heightened immunological reactivity, usually from another disease process, such as inflammatory bowel disease, rheumatoid arthritis, non-Hodgkin's lymphoma or granulomatosis with polyangiitis. Ulcers generally respond to steroids; surgery is rarely indicated and may exacerbate the condition.


Topic: HIDRADENITIS SUPPURATIVA

Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery; 28th edition; chapter 45 ; page number: 643.

choices.text: Genetic and acquired risk factors are responsible for this condition
The nodular form of this disease is the most common form
Breslow thickness is the most important prognostic indicator
Sentinel node biopsy is useful for staging

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about the condition seen in the below clinical photograph except_______
questions.solution:
• Superficial spreading melanoma (SSM).
    • This is the most common presentation (70%); usually arises in a pre-existing nevus after several years of slow change, followed by rapid growth in the months before presentation.Nodularity within SSM heralds the onset of the vertical growth phase.
  • Nodular melanoma (NM)
    • NM accounts for 15% of all malignant melanoma and tends to be more aggressive than SSM, with a shorter clinical onset.
    • These lesions often arise de novo in skin and are more common in men than in women, often presenting in middle age and usually on the trunk, head or neck.



Topic: MALIGNANT MELANOMA

Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery; 28th edition; chapter 45 ; page number:656.

questions.text: The lesion arises from the SUCQUET- HOYER CANAL is________
questions.solution:
Option A :

These are angiomata that appear (and may disappear) spontaneously at puberty or in two-thirds of pregnant women, usually disappearing in the puerperium .Spider naevi are also associated with chronic liver disease. They can be treated with intense pulsed light or pulsed-dye laser.


Option B :

These share many histological characteristics of haemangiomata and are probably a subtype thereof . Most are small (0.5–1.5 cm), raised, pedunculated, soft, red nodular lesions showing superficial ulceration and a tendency to bleed after trivial trauma. They should be excised with a minimal margin.


Option C :

This arises from a subcutaneous arteriovenous shunt (Sucquet–Hoyer canals), especially in the corium of the nail bed. Typically,it is a small, purple nodule measuring a few millimeters in size, which is disproportionately painful in response to insignificant stimuli, including cold exposure Subungual varieties may be invisible causes of paroxysmal digital pain.


Option D :

A rare, highly malignant tumour arising from the endothelial cells. The lymphangiosarcoma variant arises from lymphatic endothelium and can develop in lymphoedematous tissue, particularly an extremity. Proliferation is rapid with early systemic spread.


Topic: Hoyer canal

Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery; 28th edition; chapter 45 ; page number: 662.
